headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Horizon National Corp. Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the conference over to your
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Horizon National Corp. Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the conference over to your host, Ms. Aarti Bowman, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Please note that the press release and financial supplement which announced our earnings, as well as the slide presentation we'll use in this call this morning, are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.fhnc.c
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Please note that the press release and financial supplement which announced our earnings, as well as the slide presentation we'll use in this call this morning, are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.fhnc.com.
In this call, we will mention forward-looking statements and non-GAAP information. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking information for a number of reasons outlined in our earnings announcements materials and in our most recent annual and quarterly reports. Our forward-looking statements reflect our views today, and we are not obligated to update them. The non-GAAP information is identified as such in our earnings announcement materials and in the slide presentation for this call and is reconciled to GAAP information in those materials. Also, please remember that this webcast on our website is the only authorized record of this call.
This morning's speakers include our CEO, Bryan Jordan; and our CFO, BJ Losch. Additionally, our Chief Credit Officer, Greg Jardine, will be available with Bryan and BJ for questions.
With that, I'll turn it over to Bryan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Aarti. Good morning, and thanks for joining the call. During the third quarter, we continued to successfully on our strategic priorities by controlling what we can control. Our core businesses performed well. Regional bank pretax income was up
componenttext:
Thank you, Aarti. Good morning, and thanks for joining the call. During the third quarter, we continued to successfully on our strategic priorities by controlling what we can control. Our core businesses performed well. Regional bank pretax income was up 26% linked quarter, and Capital Markets revenues increased 26%.
We made progress in lowering expenses in our core businesses. Balance sheet trends were favorable with period end loans up 1%. Average core deposits up 2%, and consolidated net interest margin was up modestly. We also made headway in exiting Non-Strategic business by selling about $150 million of nonperforming loans.
On Slide 4. We're making solid progress in strengthening our core businesses and working hard to overcome economic and regulatory headwinds. Our bankers are focused on providing exceptional service, expanding customer relationship and proactively soliciting new business. As a result, we've seen solid market share gains across our footprint. According to recent FDIC data, our deposits in Tennessee increased 6.5% over last year compared to the 2.5% growth rate in the markets we serve. We retained our top ranking in our west and east regions, and we continue to make progress in middle Tennessee. For the second year in a row, we outpaced the market in Nashville as our deposits grew 7.4%, and our share increased 30 basis points.
We're also seeing an encouraging loan growth trends. Today, our bankers have made almost 40,000 calls on existing and prospective customers. This effort has paid off as period end loans in the regional bank were up 5% from last quarter, driven by loans to mortgage companies, corporate borrowers and asset-based lending. We remain focused on replacing our lower yielding Non-Strategic loans with better priced relationship created assets. Again, our strategy is working.
Despite competitive loan pricing pressures, loan yield and the bank were relatively stable from second to third quarter.
The regional bank posted 2% total revenue growth second to third quarter, driven by higher net interest income and steady fee income. Implementation of the Durbin amendment this month will pressure banking industry fees, and we expect roughly a $20 million impact to annual revenue.
To offset lost revenue, we continue to make pricing adjustments, but we are taking a thoughtful approach to make sure we provide true customer value. For example, beginning later this month, we are initiating a $0.04 per charge per PIN debit transaction, $0.14 cents on signature transactions and capping the monthly fee at a maximum of $3.
Capital Markets had a strong quarter with fixed income averaging daily, with fixed income average daily revenue increasing 28% to $1.4 million in the third quarter from the second quarter.
Our unique business model, which is focused on distribution and not proprietary trading, combined with the depth and diversification of our customer base across the depository and non-depository sectors positioned us well for market conditions.
Productivity and efficiency improvement remains a top priority for us. We made good progress in the third quarter, with regional bank expenses down 4% and an improved efficiency ratio of 66% in the bank. However, environmental costs remain elevated as mortgage repurchase provision expense increased from last quarter.
In our core businesses, we are on track with our efficiency initiatives and now expect $124 million in cost savings. We estimate that we realized an annualized $88 million of cost saves in our third quarter run rate.
Our productivity efforts are starting to pay off. For example, revenue per FTE in the regional bank increased 5% from last quarter. We continue to work toward our goal of achieving the 60% to 65% consolidated efficiency ratio.
Turning to credit quality. We were able to accelerate the reduction of our nonperforming loans, selling approximately $150 million in net book value of nonperformers. These NPLs were mostly in our Non-Strategic Permanent Mortgage portfolio, and the loss on sale impacted third quarter provision by $36 million. 
For the quarter, consolidated provision was $32 million, and total net charge-offs were $106 million. The loan sales impacted third quarter charge-offs accounting for 45% of total net charge-offs.
To sum up. Third quarter results demonstrated that we are continuing to successfully execute, as I said, controlling what we can control, which is resulting in a solid core business performance. BJ will now take you through the detailed financial review and I'll be back with some closing comments. BJ?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bryan. Good morning, everybody. I'll start on Slide 6. Net income available to shareholders was $36 million, and the earnings per share were $0.14 in the third quarter compared to the second quarter's net income of $20 million and EPS of $0.08. Co
componenttext:
Thanks, Bryan. Good morning, everybody. I'll start on Slide 6. Net income available to shareholders was $36 million, and the earnings per share were $0.14 in the third quarter compared to the second quarter's net income of $20 million and EPS of $0.08. Core business net income was $94 million compared to $27 million in the second quarter. While third quarter's bottom line was solid, there were also some significant items. We executed nonperforming loan sales, as Bryan said, approximating $150 million in net book value. Provision impact on loss on these sales was $36 million. We also sold some piece of shares in the third quarter for a securities gains of $35 million. Expenses related to our restructuring, repositioning and efficiency initiatives were $2 million, down from $17 million in the second quarter. And additionally, I think as previously announced, divestiture resulted in an after-tax gain of about $5 million with discontinued ops.
Moving to Slide 7. Take a look at some segment highlights. Pretax income in the regional bank increased to $93 million from $74 million in the second quarter. We booked a provision credit of $22.7 million compared to $13.7 million in the second quarter, as we saw continued credit improvement in our loan portfolios. 
Revenues were up 2%. NII was up primarily from a higher volumes of loans to mortgage. Fees were stable. Regional bank expenses declined $6 million linked quarter, and were down $15 million from third quarter 2010. 
In our capital market segment, pretax income increased to $28 million in the third quarter compared to a pretax loss of $20 million in the second, which included a $36.7 million litigation settlement expense. Fixed income average daily revenues increased $1.4 million in the third quarter from $1.1 million in the second quarter. Growth in average daily revenues reflects the strength of our extensive distribution network and our substantial penetration of the depository customer segment, combined with favorable market conditions. 
Following the feds early August announcement of an extended loan rate interest rate environment, we saw our customers begin to deploy a greater amount of their excess liquidity, resulting in increased fixed income buying activity. Since we generate the vast majority of our revenue from sales and distribution activities on the behalf of our clients, we benefit when there is strong buying activity while avoiding significant negative trading results experienced by the firms.
We believe that in the near term, fixed income average daily revenues could stay elevated within this range. However, it's always that performance remains sensitive to interest rate changes and the overall economic environment other factors. 
In Corporate segment, pretax income was $19 million in the third quarter compared to a loss of $27 million in the second. Third quarter included $35 million in securities gains from the sale of Visa stock and lower restructuring of expenses. 
In the Non-Strategic second, pretax income was a loss of $98 million compared to a loss of $13 million in the second quarter. The increase pretax loss was driven by higher loan loss provisions, primarily driven by the loan sales. We increased mortgage repurchase provision expense, as well as elevated cost from the transfer to a new self-services and a negative adjustment in our mortgage warehouse valuations.
On Slide 8, we'll take a look at balance sheet and then net interest margin trends. Consolidated net interest margin was relatively stable at 3.23% compared to 3.20% in the second quarter. Core business net interest margin was 3.52%. Positive drivers for margin included higher loan volume, lower deposit costs, which were somewhat offset by lower reinvestment rates in the securities portfolio. Over the next several quarters, we expect to defend the margins by replacing lower yielding non-strategic assets with better priced regional bank assets further reducing deposit pricing and experiencing less of a drag from nonperformers. However, there's likely to be continued pressure with lower reinvestment yields in the securities portfolio, and margin is likely to decline modestly by a few basis points per quarter over the next several quarters.
As you can see on Slide 9, loan pipeline trends in our regional bank continue to be encouraging as loan commitments and loans funded are up compared to last year. Although borrowers remain cautious, we're seeing areas of demand from customers in our corporate asset-based lending CRE and mortgage warehouse lending segment. With revenue, demand pricing a structure remains competitive. Our loan yields in the regional bank were relatively stable at 4.01% compared to last quarter's yield at 4.02%. Given the competitive environment, we expect yields will be under pressure. Nonetheless, new loans being booking in the regional bank continue to be better priced than regional banking and non-strategic assets that are running off our balance sheet.
Moving to expenses on Slide 10. We're very pleased with our continued progress year. Consolidated expenses declined 6% from last quarter. Regional banking expenses decreased 4% as we continue to implement cost-saving initiatives. Productivity and efficiency actions in the third quarter include reductions of FTEs, lower discretionary spending and gaining efficiency from exited businesses. We will continue to evaluate efficiency actions such as consolidating branches and further process improvement. And we should also benefit from technology investments. Over the long term, we continue to target a 25% reduction from the level of 2010 consolidated expenses, mostly by the end of 2013.
Moving onto mortgage repurchase on Slide 11. Linked quarter, mortgage repurchase provision expense increased to $53 million from $25 million. Net realized losses matched provision leaving reserves flat at $169 million. The rescission rate stayed steady in July and August, but trended lower in September reflecting a higher mix of mortgage insurance related resolutions, leading to higher loss content. 
In the quarter, the GSCs made a push to results unresolved repurchase claims based on MI coverage loss. To some extent, this accelerated charge-offs and contributed to third quarter higher level of losses. Our operational pipeline dropped from $451 million to $418 million with new request of $200 million and resolution of $237 million. The operational pipeline includes request where mortgage insurance calculations are under review. Once this coverage is lost, it comes out of our operational pipeline, but we continue to consider these loans in the reserve calculation.
The GSC appear to be more aggressive than the recovery efforts. Quarter to quarter, we are likely to see volatility in repurchase expense from the variances in the mix of both inflows and resolutions. Sitting here today, we expect our repurchase inflows to be reasonably steady, resolutions to continue to be strong and we also still believe we're on the backside of GSE-related repurchase request.
Moving to Slide 12, for a minute, on private mortgage securitizations. We still have had no repurchase request from resecuritization to date. We still currently have 4 lawsuits related to private mortgage securitization completing the FHFA lawsuit. Our private mortgage securitization have generally performed favorably overall of the industry cohort benchmarks. As you can see on the slide, 66% of private mortgage securitizations are outperforming industry cohort on cue loss, and 81% of these securitizations are outperforming cohorts on 60-day-plus delinquencies. 
Our mix is different. We did no subprime, and additionally, reps and warranties are genetically more limited than for GSE hold-on sales. Considering the differences between the private securitizations and GSE loans that we've outlined on the slide, we continue to believe right now that our private securitization risk is likely to become significantly less than our experience with GSEs, which continues to be manageable as the earnings headwinds.
Moving to asset quality on Slide 13. Credit quality metrics continue to be positive. NPAs declined. Net charge-offs, excluding the loan sales, were down. Loan sales of about $150 million and net book value included $126 million from our perm mortgage portfolio and about $24 million from our commercial loan portfolio. UPB on the sold loans was $220 million, reflecting a 47% blended mark on the loan sales. Reserves decreased $74 million including $12 million associated with the loan sales. Despite several quarters, the reserve releases or reserves to loans remained healthy at $277 million. Given that our credit quality trends are generally favorable, we expect additional reserve releases, but the rate of reserve decrease could slow down depending on the economic environment.
Moving to Slide 14. Nonperforming assets declined to 22% linked quarter primarily due to the loan sales and upgrades in the commercial portfolio. In addition, the broad-based improvement in our loan portfolios, we expect that the sale of our nonperforming should be favorable to overall credit quality metrics in the future.
Wrapping up on Slide 15. Our core businesses showed good progress in reaching our long-term targets as we focus on controlling what we can control with solid trends in the regional bank, continued strong performance in our Capital Markets business and improving productivity and efficiency. Although the Non-Strategic segment and mortgage repurchase remain a drag, I'm pleased with the momentum in the bank and in our Capital Markets business. Bryan?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, BJ. Heading into the final quarter of 2011, I'm encouraged by the First Horizon team's progress in successfully executing our strategy. And I'm confident that we have the ability to continue to streamline and strengthen our business model, prof
componenttext:
Thank you, BJ. Heading into the final quarter of 2011, I'm encouraged by the First Horizon team's progress in successfully executing our strategy. And I'm confident that we have the ability to continue to streamline and strengthen our business model, profitably growing our core businesses, significantly improving productivity and efficiency in favor of the shifting our asset mix. We're also taking a disciplined approach to capital deployment. And today, we launched $100 million common stock repurchase program.
We and the industry are facing economic and the regulatory headwinds, and we remain in a slow growth environment. But with our dedicated team and customer focus, we will continue to make steady progress. Thank you, and now we'll take your questions. Operator?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011

componenttextpreview: This is Greg Jardine. Well, I think, a couple things. One, that was a sale of nonperforming assets, and it was a bulk sale. And as I mentioned in other calls, we explore the market all the time, and what we found in this particular case was that the bid a
componenttext: This is Greg Jardine. Well, I think, a couple things. One, that was a sale of nonperforming assets, and it was a bulk sale. And as I mentioned in other calls, we explore the market all the time, and what we found in this particular case was that the bid ask was with in an area of which we feel comfortable with. So the 188 the UPB, the net book value was 67% of that. And so, we had a 60, another 68% execution against net book value, and we took a significant tail risk off by nonperforming for mortgages. So in that case, Bob, we feel very comfortable. As you know, we have done some bulk sales, not something of this size because we get basically good execution on one-off sales. But this made sense for the rate we got.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, one last question, Bryan. Just thinking about the $100 million share buyback and how you came to that number, did you guys request more? Is it an ongoing process? And when do you guys, if you used this as up, do you think you can be eligible to
componenttext: And then, one last question, Bryan. Just thinking about the $100 million share buyback and how you came to that number, did you guys request more? Is it an ongoing process? And when do you guys, if you used this as up, do you think you can be eligible to go back and talk about increasing that?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me try to start with the calendar. We think, based on everything we've been able to gather that the process around the other than 19 is not as a structured a process. So I think it's a continuing dialogue with the regulators. So with that said, we thi
componenttext: Let me try to start with the calendar. We think, based on everything we've been able to gather that the process around the other than 19 is not as a structured a process. So I think it's a continuing dialogue with the regulators. So with that said, we think that we have the opportunity to revisit the issue in the future. We made an initial request of $100 million from our perspective that capital management is a process. We worked through it with the regulators, and we'll continue to evaluate the timing of repurchases and so on and so forth. So that was our initial request. We will work with the regulated to the future as we work through that. We'll continue to evaluate how we manage our capital basis. As I've said in the past, we think that we have a very strong capital base. We think over time as the economy improves, we'll have a fair amount of excess capital to deploy, either in repurchasing stock or investment in the business. But we're going to be very disciplined in the way we do it, and that involves working with our regulators.

componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Bryan. As you probably noted, the authorization approved by the board expires in August of next year. We're going to take response, and we're going to try to buy at attractive valuations. And if that means being slow and deliberate, we'll be
componenttext: Ken, this is Bryan. As you probably noted, the authorization approved by the board expires in August of next year. We're going to take response, and we're going to try to buy at attractive valuations. And if that means being slow and deliberate, we'll be slow and deliberate. If it means accelerating, we'll do that as well. But we're going to pick our spots, and we're going to look at it on a day-to-day basis as market conditions dictate, we'll take advantage of that.

componenttext: We obviously have more nonperforming loans in our portfolio, and we do explore and we'll continue to explore the market when the opportunity is acceptable to us, we may impact, do another sales. But we don't feel that we're compelled to have to go out into a book sale, but we will on an opportunistic basis look at opportunities.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011

componenttext: Just on the GSCs viewpoint, you said the increase this quarter in terms of lost content was because of the push the GSCs was doing on the MI loans. All things considered, if we sort of look at the trend-in losses, backing out that increase, is it feasible to increase we're bank down to sort of more trendline reduction or are we more to kind of a higher level going forward?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ken, it's BJ. Here's how I tell you to think about it. There's 2 pieces to the mortgage repurchase provision, as you know. There's the actual charge-offs so the losses we realized and then, there's the calculation of the reserve. With the latter, the rese
componenttext: Ken, it's BJ. Here's how I tell you to think about it. There's 2 pieces to the mortgage repurchase provision, as you know. There's the actual charge-offs so the losses we realized and then, there's the calculation of the reserve. With the latter, the reserve is harder to pinpoint because you obviously have to look at the mix of resolutions and inflows and all that kind of stuff on a forward-looking basis. But from a charge-off perspective, the way I see it is this was an acceleration in this quarter. And therefore, the realized losses that we saw this quarter may, in fact, be elevated or high. And I would expect that charge-offs may very likely come down from this level over the next few quarters. Again, the provision itself will depend on how we look at the reserve and the mix of it, but I would expect that the actual charge-offs may likely come down.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Alexopoulos from JPMorgan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011

componenttext: I want to ask you, just announcing the stock buyback, what changed that now is the right time to announce this, are you feeling better on mortgage repurchase risk or is it just the stock below tangible book is the best use of capital?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as a sort of headed in the second quarter call, Steve, that we're going to be disciplined about deploying capital. And I said at the time, we will work with our regulators, and we'll work through that process in the third quarter with our regulators
componenttext: Well, as a sort of headed in the second quarter call, Steve, that we're going to be disciplined about deploying capital. And I said at the time, we will work with our regulators, and we'll work through that process in the third quarter with our regulators. As I said to Bob, we made an initial request of $100 million. And I guess nothing else. We had a press release going out this morning on earnings, so we're just attach it to that.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: So we shouldn't read into it that you're feeling better about credit quality, mortgage repurchase or things like that?
componenttext: So we shouldn't read into it that you're feeling better about credit quality, mortgage repurchase or things like that?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, I don't know how you would define better. I guess I would tell you that we feel good about credit quality. We feel like credit quality has been improving. That's consistent with what we've been saying for an extended period of time. Our mor
componenttext: Well, I guess, I don't know how you would define better. I guess I would tell you that we feel good about credit quality. We feel like credit quality has been improving. That's consistent with what we've been saying for an extended period of time. Our mortgage repurchase exposure, BJ talked a fair amount about both the GSEs and the private. We do think we're on the backside with the GSCs with 3 years out from the last loan we originated and sold to the GSCs, the private securitizations for the reasons that BJ described in detail. We feel that the private securitization exposure is likely to be significantly less than the exposure to the GSCs. And we think that it will manage below the earnings headwinds. So from our perspective, our balance sheet is getting better. I think our balance sheet is better today than it was 3 months ago. I think it's better than it was 6 months ago. I think it's better than it was a 1.5 year ago. So I think every quarter, our balance sheet continues to get better, and some of these actions do resolve nonperforming assets, the residential mortgages that we've talked about, the NPA sales. So I feel good about our balance sheet, I feel good about our capital position and I feel good about the trajectory our business is on. I think our bankers, our capital market teams are executing very well in customer business. All of that said, we feel like we've got a very strong capital base. We think it's appropriate to manage that capital base smartly in a disciplined fashion. And then appropriate return excess capital shareholders, and that's the step we've taken.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Craig Siegenthaler of Credit Suisse.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Firstly, on the Capital Markets revenues, I'm wondering what level of activity you're seeing kind of quarter to date here in October and at the end of September relative to the July and August levels?
componenttext: Firstly, on the Capital Markets revenues, I'm wondering what level of activity you're seeing kind of quarter to date here in October and at the end of September relative to the July and August levels?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's BJ. I would say, kind of as I said in my prepared remarks that we still see strong flows and activity in that business. We do business on behalf of our clients, so we're sales and distribution, not trading. And so, when there's a lot of callable acti
componenttext: It's BJ. I would say, kind of as I said in my prepared remarks that we still see strong flows and activity in that business. We do business on behalf of our clients, so we're sales and distribution, not trading. And so, when there's a lot of callable activity on the agency side for instance, or the flattening of the curve tends to benefit us because clients had cash flows that are rolling off, and they need to reinvest it at rates higher than cash. So all of those things tend to favor us, and we're still seeing those trends going into October.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, we heard your comments lead to higher volatility trends given the more aggressive nature of the GSE putbacks. But given the more that you purchase losses now, if you look at reserves coverage in less than 1 year, I'm wondering should really expe
componenttext: And then, we heard your comments lead to higher volatility trends given the more aggressive nature of the GSE putbacks. But given the more that you purchase losses now, if you look at reserves coverage in less than 1 year, I'm wondering should really expect us to decline from here?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let me give you a little more color than give a couple questions ago, Craig. Our losses, our actual losses in July were $10 million. Our losses in August were $13 million, and our losses in September were $29 million. The high watermark for any part
componenttext: Well, let me give you a little more color than give a couple questions ago, Craig. Our losses, our actual losses in July were $10 million. Our losses in August were $13 million, and our losses in September were $29 million. The high watermark for any particular month over the last 18 months had been around $14.8 million or so. So that, coupled with the communication that we did receive from the GSEs as they wanted to resolve certain types of claims by 9/30, leads me to believe that there were certainly an acceleration of our charge-offs. So those are all things that we have contemplated, we have always contemplated in our reserve calculation. So even with a higher level of charge-offs, we didn't necessarily see higher level of reserves for future content based on what we see in the pipeline today, and what I call our operational pipeline continues to go down. So what that means is that we have folks literally working on claims once MI coverage is actually lost, there's literally nothing else for our folks to work on. So it comes out of our pipeline but it continues to be accounted for in our reserves. I see that as a positive sign because at some point, we don't have to work these anymore, and we're just waiting to literally resolve the paperwork on it one way or another. So I continue to see good progress, good trends, good work from our folks. And as I said before, I actually believe that the level of charge-offs are likely to be down over the next few quarters.

componenttext: Well, again, that life was them one that was part of the foreclosure assessment process. They are our subservicers. So we are working with them and monitoring what they are doing closely to ensure that what they worked on, on our behalf was done in the right way. But as I've said before, that's their issue, but we are working with them and monitoring closely our risks related to it.

componenttext: Jefferson, this is Bryan. I think we're a ways away from the process. At this point, none of the discovery, the responses, it's very, very early in that process. And I think this is a process that's going to take some time to resolve. As we've said in the past, we feel like we've got a strong position, and we intend to try to vigorously defend that position.

componenttext: Can you give me a sense of what a normalized size for the mortgage warehouse portfolio within the C&I book, the mortgage warehouse company's corresponding banking at $1.1 billion?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bryan, it's BJ. As you can see, that's really going to fluctuate. I think we've had a high of $1 billion or $1.1 billion, and something as low as $300 million to $400 million. So I'm not sure I can tell you from quarter to quarter. It depends on what the
componenttext: Bryan, it's BJ. As you can see, that's really going to fluctuate. I think we've had a high of $1 billion or $1.1 billion, and something as low as $300 million to $400 million. So I'm not sure I can tell you from quarter to quarter. It depends on what the mortgage applications look like across the industry. And so, it's going to fluctuate, but probably between these 2 compounds.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, as we think of kind the quarter NIM, can you just remind us in the regional core banking segment, the NIM is actually higher than loan yields. Is there kind of the deposit pricing, transfer credit and if so, does the Non-Strategic segment pay fo
componenttext: And then, as we think of kind the quarter NIM, can you just remind us in the regional core banking segment, the NIM is actually higher than loan yields. Is there kind of the deposit pricing, transfer credit and if so, does the Non-Strategic segment pay for that or does the Corporate segment pay for that?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is a funds credit that the bank gets for deposits. And no, the Non-Strategic does not pay for that. It's balanced out in our Corporate segment in the way we balance the balance sheet in our co.
componenttext: Yes, there is a funds credit that the bank gets for deposits. And no, the Non-Strategic does not pay for that. It's balanced out in our Corporate segment in the way we balance the balance sheet in our co.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Miller of FBR Capital markets.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Jessica Ribner for Paul. I have a couple questions on the trading revenue and also the decline in mortgage revenue. Where did the decline in mortgage revenue come from, and can we expect this number going forward?
componenttext: This is Jessica Ribner for Paul. I have a couple questions on the trading revenue and also the decline in mortgage revenue. Where did the decline in mortgage revenue come from, and can we expect this number going forward?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think on mortgage -- this is BJ, I think our mortgage net hedging results were about is $7 million versus $15 million last quarter. We saw, after the Fed's announcement on operation twist, a lot of volatility in our hedge assets as it relates to our MSR
componenttext: I think on mortgage -- this is BJ, I think our mortgage net hedging results were about is $7 million versus $15 million last quarter. We saw, after the Fed's announcement on operation twist, a lot of volatility in our hedge assets as it relates to our MSR book. So we saw the positive ineffectiveness come down pretty maturely, but it was still positive for the quarter. So when we planned for this, we planned for very modest revenues. And so, we plan for the $7 million to $10 million range every quarter. So this is roughly within the range that we would model internally.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I know you were saying that you're trading revenue is mostly client driven? Is that commissions or just market making?
componenttext: I know you were saying that you're trading revenue is mostly client driven? Is that commissions or just market making?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess the point I was making is if you look at our fixed income business model versus some other ones out on the street, we do all of our business really for the benefit of our clients. So we're doing sales, we're distributing product, we're matching up
componenttext: I guess the point I was making is if you look at our fixed income business model versus some other ones out on the street, we do all of our business really for the benefit of our clients. So we're doing sales, we're distributing product, we're matching up buyers and sellers, and we're not necessarily trading. We are not trading on our own book. And I think that's a quite different model from what you'll see out in the street. And so, when you see volatility and fixed income results elsewhere, you may see it from trading results. Whereas for us, it's a literally going to be related to the level of activity or the volatility or the volume of what you're seeing in the market. And when that happens, we're going to benefit in that environment.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Pancari of Evermore Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Pancari of Evermore Partners.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the private label side, can you talk again why you think the losses, the risk will be significant less than what you're seeing on the GSC side? I know you're emphasizing up this quarter again, particularly since you haven't seen any putbacks yet?
componenttext: On the private label side, can you talk again why you think the losses, the risk will be significant less than what you're seeing on the GSC side? I know you're emphasizing up this quarter again, particularly since you haven't seen any putbacks yet?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, it's BJ. I think if you go back and look at what I said in the prepared remarks, you can go back and look at what we said in second quarter, we just look at what the -- what we've experienced with GSEs, and we take a look at what the reps and warran
componenttext: John, it's BJ. I think if you go back and look at what I said in the prepared remarks, you can go back and look at what we said in second quarter, we just look at what the -- what we've experienced with GSEs, and we take a look at what the reps and warranties were on those types of loans versus what the reps and warranties were on privates and the significant differences between the 2, which are mitigating factors, number one. Number 2, we look at our performance versus industry to get a general feel of how we're performing. Third, we did note some subprime the securitization, and I think if you look at the industry mix, there was 30-plus percent of subprime done during this time period. So all of these things kind of put in a bucket, and the settlement, whether or not it goes through, provided somewhat a benchmark, if you will. And as we outlined in the second quarter, our delinquencies and defaults relative to that portfolio are significantly better. And so, we couple all that GSE stuff, couple anything that we know externally, we study our securitizations in detail, and we come to the completion sitting here today that it could be significantly less than what we experienced in just use.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: One thing I would add, John, this is Bryan, the starting balances originated were roughly half of what we originated. And if you look at the mix there, it was about 40% John Baugh, about 60% all day. John Bowe has performed very well as BJ pointed out in
componenttext: One thing I would add, John, this is Bryan, the starting balances originated were roughly half of what we originated. And if you look at the mix there, it was about 40% John Baugh, about 60% all day. John Bowe has performed very well as BJ pointed out in his prepared comments. And if you factor in just be aggregate size of what was originated, you factor in potentially the statute of limitations and other factors, we do conclude that is significantly less in all likelihood than what we experienced in the GSE side.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Fitzsimmons from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Fitzsimmons from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't want to really spend that much time of this issue, Bryan, but if it is the big issue for the stock or what I mean issue out there on when does this, when does this play out, what the magnitude will be? Would have to imagine having gone through thi
componenttext: I don't want to really spend that much time of this issue, Bryan, but if it is the big issue for the stock or what I mean issue out there on when does this, when does this play out, what the magnitude will be? Would have to imagine having gone through this process with the regulators and while maybe you can't be that specific with us, you can give us a general sense that if they're going to approve you to do buybacks, I would think they'll be interested on what the exposure is and how long it takes to play out. So I know we haven't had a private request come yet, but from an investor's point of view who's trying to gauge the timeline of when this plays out, what's your best guess and how is it factor to the best analysis to what it took place with the regulators for the buybacks?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Kevin, the timeline on it is going to take a while. I mentioned how it was on the FHA lawsuit. That's going to take a while, but I think, it's appropriate for us to take the time to start the discovery process to defend the position. If there are -- there
componenttext: Kevin, the timeline on it is going to take a while. I mentioned how it was on the FHA lawsuit. That's going to take a while, but I think, it's appropriate for us to take the time to start the discovery process to defend the position. If there are -- there's the factors that will take a while to work through, and it's not something that's going to be a quick resolution. That said, as you would expect, when we make application or consult with our regulators to manage our capital level, we walk through stress testing is significant risk in the balance sheet. And we laid that out over time, when we laid that out and compare to where our balance sheet is, what our credit quality looks like, what our GSE exposure looks like, what our private securities potentially exposure looks like, and we put all that together and we stress our capital. And we put forward a proposal, and the regulators are -- they are with the organization and evaluate us on a long-term basis. So it's a process that is always put together unfortunately then work with the pipeline or in terms of when the GSCs or when the private label securities might come to a regulation, it's going to take some time. As we said, we will continue to work on it. And I would add this, that in some sense, time is our friend when it comes to dealing with the GSEs and the private label securities. Every day that goes by, more loans pay down, more loans pay off. The exposure continues to reduce. And as we pointed out a couple of times, we have an originated or sold any of these loans going back over 3 years and over that period. The last one was originated and sold were August of 2008. Over that period, you've gone through the worst hosing crisis and possibly the nation's history, and we've gone through a 25-, 30-year high in unemployment. So it's just going to take some time to work through it. We're trying to be patient and deliver it in the way to do that. We're looking for opportunities to resolve it, but it's a process that we just have to work through.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tony Davis of Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tony Davis of Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: There are, I guess, some issues at the bank outside of rep and warranty. Aside from warehouse, has the strength that you saw in the C&I and CRE book company in August or July, Bryan, has that continued into the September and October? And has there been an
componenttext: There are, I guess, some issues at the bank outside of rep and warranty. Aside from warehouse, has the strength that you saw in the C&I and CRE book company in August or July, Bryan, has that continued into the September and October? And has there been any improvement in the rate?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll let Greg sort of help me out here, but the pipelines in early October were sort of consistent with where we saw at the end of September. They might have been a little bit lower than they would have been going in to the early second quarter but still
componenttext: I'll let Greg sort of help me out here, but the pipelines in early October were sort of consistent with where we saw at the end of September. They might have been a little bit lower than they would have been going in to the early second quarter but still pretty solid. We're still seeing read in the book customer activity, and our competition is still fairly intense for loan deals that are out there. As I said for several quarters, we're still seeing later-cycle behaviors in terms of pricing and structure. But overall, pipelines have continued to be modest but strong relative to an economic recovery that sort of run in the low single digits.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I couldn't add any much more to that, Brad. I think that's exactly what we see. Competition, one thing I would say is that the competition in the income CRE space has increased kind of quarter-over-quarter, as some of the larger banks have come to the mar
componenttext: I couldn't add any much more to that, Brad. I think that's exactly what we see. Competition, one thing I would say is that the competition in the income CRE space has increased kind of quarter-over-quarter, as some of the larger banks have come to the market. But it's still in a relatively good shape.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Any further comment on that, and in terms of maybe credit spreads today and income CRE or small business, middle-market C&I versus 3 to 6 months ago?
componenttext: Any further comment on that, and in terms of maybe credit spreads today and income CRE or small business, middle-market C&I versus 3 to 6 months ago?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think in C&I, it's going to depend upon really the segment we're in. In the corporate area, that's pretty transparent in terms of what trends are. Small business lending, those spreads are typically holding fairly stable. In kind of the middle-market is
componenttext: I think in C&I, it's going to depend upon really the segment we're in. In the corporate area, that's pretty transparent in terms of what trends are. Small business lending, those spreads are typically holding fairly stable. In kind of the middle-market is where you see a lot of pressure in terms of structure and pricing. And some banks have kind of got out of the CRE business and gone into the C&I space. I have the exact number quarter-over-quarter in front of me, but we're seeing some pressure there and in the municipal market as well. There's some aggressive pricing in the municipal market.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tony, this is Bryan again. If you look at it over the last couple of quarters really, the last 1.5 year have, we saw spreads and new originations continue to build. They start to flatten out some in the early part of this year, and I expect them to sort o
componenttext: Tony, this is Bryan again. If you look at it over the last couple of quarters really, the last 1.5 year have, we saw spreads and new originations continue to build. They start to flatten out some in the early part of this year, and I expect them to sort of to be flat to down. It's just a little bit over the next couple of quarters you see this pricing structure pressure in the marketplace.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Reynolds of Wunderlich Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Reynolds of Wunderlich Securities.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess this is kind of a following up to Tony's question. Since July and August, the world apparently seems to come to an end if you watch the news and all, and I'm trying to figure out how behaviors have changed, not just what do the numbers show, but a
componenttext: I guess this is kind of a following up to Tony's question. Since July and August, the world apparently seems to come to an end if you watch the news and all, and I'm trying to figure out how behaviors have changed, not just what do the numbers show, but as you talk to customers out there, maybe across the State of Tennessee and regional banks, do you get the sense that customers are getting more nervous or maybe adapting to the environment that we're in right now. Has their actual behavior changed on the ground? Have they hunkered up, hunkered down and gone into hiding, or are they just sort of grinding right through this situation?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Kevin, this is Bryan. I think I've said a number of times that I think people sort of nervousness in this environment is directly proportional to how much TV they watch, how much they read about it. My sense of our customers is that they are continuing to
componenttext: Kevin, this is Bryan. I think I've said a number of times that I think people sort of nervousness in this environment is directly proportional to how much TV they watch, how much they read about it. My sense of our customers is that they are continuing to act in a way that is consistent with the modest low single digits type recovery. Clearly, people are paying attention a little more to what's going on in Europe and what's going on in the U.S. economy because it is so prevalent in the media. But it doesn't feel to us at this point that customers have really pulled back. I would say that the customer base that we do business with and our surrounding marketplace feels to me a lot like it's been through 2008. It's been through a tough environment in 2009. People have right sized costs, they got their expectations right sized for the economic environment that we're in, and people continue to forward at a modest pace.

componenttext: Chris, it's BJ. I think that it's a positive thing, what we're seeing. It's just movement between some of the segments. But what our long-term target are to have 350% to 4% net interest margins across the company core businesses is where we're going to get it. And that's low rate environment, it's hard to defend that margin. Once interest rates normalized, based on our assets sensitivity, you should see that continue to move up. But the movement there is nothing that we're very concerned about. We're still very pleased with our margin in this quarter.

componenttextpreview: Well, I think I said in my prepared remarks that the longer this low-ate environment last, the harder it is for us to defend the margins. So the way we're doing it is better yielding assets coming on in the regional bank replacing lower yielding assets ei
componenttext: Well, I think I said in my prepared remarks that the longer this low-ate environment last, the harder it is for us to defend the margins. So the way we're doing it is better yielding assets coming on in the regional bank replacing lower yielding assets either in the bank or in our Non-Strategic. We'll continue to do that. We'll continue to bring our deposit costs down marginally. But the reinvestment rates that we're seeing on the portfolio will certainly create a headwind. So the way I see the margin over the next several quarters is us defending flat as well as we can, but mostly most likely seeing a few basis points decline quarter over the next several quarters.

componenttextpreview: This is an environment where I think M&A is going to be reasonably slow for a while. I think with valuations hit as hard as they've been hit over the last 90 days, I don't think it makes a lot of sense in many ways for providers and maybe for sellers. So
componenttext: This is an environment where I think M&A is going to be reasonably slow for a while. I think with valuations hit as hard as they've been hit over the last 90 days, I don't think it makes a lot of sense in many ways for providers and maybe for sellers. So I think it will be a little bit slower than it has been or seemed to build. And so I think that it's going to take a little time. Valuations are going to get right given the valuations of our currency. I think capital repatriation makes more sense in the short run than M&A, unless it's an extraordinarily financial transactions. So I just think things are going to be slow for a while.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Horizon National Corp. Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Please go ahead.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Please note that the press release and financial supplement which announced our earnings, as well as the slide presentation we'll use in this call this morning, are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.fhnc.c
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Please note that the press release and financial supplement which announced our earnings, as well as the slide presentation we'll use in this call this morning, are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.fhnc.com.
In this call, we will mention forward-looking statements and non-GAAP information. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking information for a number of reasons outlined in our earnings announcement materials and in our most recent annual and quarterly reports. Our forward-looking statements reflect our views today, and we are not obligated to update them. The non-GAAP information is identified as such in our earnings announcement materials and in the slide presentation for this call and is reconciled to GAAP information in those materials. Also, please remember that this webcast on our website is the only authorized record of this call.
This morning's speakers include our CEO, Bryan Jordan; and our CFO, BJ Losch. Additionally, our Chief Credit Officer, Greg Jardine, will be available with Bryan and BJ for questions.
With that, I'll turn it over to Bryan.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Aarti. Good morning and thanks for joining the call. During the third quarter, we continued to successfully execute on our strategic priorities by controlling what we can control. Our core businesses performed well. Regional bank pretax income
componenttext:
Thank you, Aarti. Good morning and thanks for joining the call. During the third quarter, we continued to successfully execute on our strategic priorities by controlling what we can control. Our core businesses performed well. Regional bank pretax income was up 26% linked quarter, and capital markets revenues increased 26%.
We made progress in lowering expenses in our core businesses. Balance sheet trends were favorable with period end loans, up 1%; average core deposits, up 2%, and consolidated net interest margin was up modestly. We also made headway in exiting non-strategic business by selling about $150 million of nonperforming loans.
On Slide 4. We're making solid progress in strengthening our core businesses and working hard to overcome economic and regulatory headwinds. Our bankers are focused on providing exceptional service, expanding customer relationship and proactively soliciting new business. As a result, we've seen solid market share gains across our footprint. According to recent FDIC data, our deposits in Tennessee increased 6.5% over last year compared to the 2.5% growth rate in the markets we serve. We retained our top ranking in our west and east regions, and we continue to make progress in middle Tennessee. For a second year in a row, we outpaced the market in Nashville as our deposits grew 7.4% and our share increased 30 basis points.
We're also seeing an encouraging loan growth trends. Today, our bankers have made almost 40,000 calls on existing and prospective customers. This effort has paid off as period end loans in the regional bank were up 5% from last quarter, driven by loans to mortgage companies, corporate borrowers and asset-based lending. We remain focused on replacing our lower yielding non-strategic loan with better price relationship oriented assets. Again, our strategy is working.
Despite competitive loan pricing pressures, loan yields and the bank were relatively stable from second to third quarter.
The regional bank posted 2% total revenue growth second to third quarter, driven by higher net interest income and steady fee income. Implementation of the Durbin amendment this month will pressure banking industry fees, and we expect roughly a $20 million impact to annual revenue.
To offset lost revenue, we continue to make pricing adjustments, but we are taking a thoughtful approach to ensure we provide true customer value. For example, beginning later this month, we are initiating a $0.04 per charge per PIN debit transaction, $0.14 on signature transactions and capping the monthly fee at a maximum of $3.
Capital markets had a strong quarter with fixed income averaging daily -- with fixed income average daily revenue increasing 28% to $1.4 million in the third quarter from the second quarter.
Our unique business model, which is focused on distribution and not proprietary trading, combined with the depth and diversification of our customer base across the depository and non-depository sectors positioned us well for market conditions.
Productivity and efficiency improvement remains a top priority for us. We made good progress in the third quarter, with regional bank expenses down 4% and an improved efficiency ratio of 66% in the bank. However, environmental costs remain elevated as mortgage repurchase provision expense increased from last quarter.
In our core businesses, we are on track with our efficiency initiatives and now expect $124 million in cost savings. We estimate that we realized an annualized $88 million of cost saves in our third quarter run rate.
Our productivity efforts are starting to pay off. For example, revenue per FTE in the regional bank increased 5% from last quarter. We continue to work toward our goal of achieving the 60% to 65% consolidated efficiency ratio.
Turning to credit quality. We were able to accelerate the reduction of our nonperforming loans, selling approximately $150 million in net book value of nonperformers. These NPLs were mostly in our non-strategic permanent mortgage portfolio, and the loss on sale impacted third quarter provision by $36 million.
For the quarter, consolidated provision was $32 million and total net charge-offs were $106 million. The loan sales impacted third quarter charge-offs, accounting for 45% of total net charge-offs.
To sum up, third quarter results demonstrated that we are continuing to successfully execute, as I said, controlling what we can control, which is resulting in solid core business performance. BJ will now take you through the detailed financial review, and I'll be back with some closing comments. BJ?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bryan. Good morning, everybody. I'll start on Slide 6. Net income available to shareholders was $36 million, and our earnings per share were $0.14 in the third quarter compared to the second quarter's net income of $20 million and EPS of $0.08. Co
componenttext:
Thanks, Bryan. Good morning, everybody. I'll start on Slide 6. Net income available to shareholders was $36 million, and our earnings per share were $0.14 in the third quarter compared to the second quarter's net income of $20 million and EPS of $0.08. Core business net income was $94 million compared to $27 million in the second quarter. While third quarter's bottom line was solid, there were also some significant items. We executed nonperforming loan sales, as Bryan said, approximating $150 million in net book value. Provision impact from loss on these sales was $36 million. We also sold some piece of shares in the third quarter as a -- for a securities gain of $35 million. Expenses related to our restructuring, repositioning and efficiency initiatives were $2 million, down from $17 million in the second quarter; and additionally, a previously announced divestiture resulted in an after-tax gain of about $5 million within discontinued ops.
Moving to Slide 7. Take a look at some segment highlights. Pretax income in the regional bank increased to $94 million from $74 million in the second quarter. We booked a provision credit of $22.7 million compared to $13.7 million in the second quarter, as we saw continued credit improvement in our loan portfolios.
Revenues were up 2%. NII was up primarily from a higher volumes of loans to mortgage companies. Fees were stable. Regional bank expenses declined $6 million linked quarter and were down $15 million from third quarter 2010.
In our capital markets segment, pretax income increased to $28 million in the third quarter compared to a pretax loss of $20 million in the second, which included a $36.7 million litigation settlement expense. Fixed income average daily revenues increased to $1.4 million in the third quarter from $1.1 million in the second. Growth in average daily revenues reflects the strength of our extensive distribution network and our substantial penetration of the depository customer segment combined with favorable market conditions.
Following the Fed's early August announcement of an extended low rate interest rate environment, we saw our customers begin to deploy a greater amount of their excess liquidity, resulting in increased fixed income buying activity. Since we generate the vast majority of our revenue from sales and distribution activities on behalf of our clients, we benefit when there is strong buying activity while avoiding significant negative trading results experienced by the firms.
We believe that in the near term, fixed income average daily revenues could stay elevated within this range. However, as always, our performance remains sensitive to interest rate changes and the overall economic environment, among other factors.
In corporate segment, pretax income was $19 million in the third quarter compared to a loss of $27 million in the second. Third quarter included $35 million in securities gains from the sale of Visa stock and lower restructuring expense. 
In the non-strategic segment, pretax income was a loss of $98 million compared to a loss of $13 million in the second quarter. The increased pretax loss was driven by a higher loan loss provision, primarily driven by the loan sales. We increased mortgage repurchase provision expense, as well as elevated cost from the transfer to a new sub-servicer and a negative adjustment in our mortgage warehouse valuation.
On Slide 8, we'll take a look at balance sheet and net interest margin trend. Consolidated net interest margin was relatively stable at 3.23% compared to 3.20% in the second quarter. Core business net interest margin was 3.52%. Positive drivers for margin included higher loan volume, lower deposit costs, which were somewhat offset by lower reinvestment rates in the securities portfolio. Over the next several quarters, we expect to defend the margin by replacing lower yielding non-strategic assets with better priced regional bank assets further reducing deposit pricing and experiencing less of a drag from nonperformers. However, there's likely to be continued pressure with lower reinvestment yields in the securities portfolio, and margin is likely to decline modestly by a few basis points per quarter over the next several quarters.
As you can see on Slide 9, loan pipeline trends in our regional bank continue to be encouraging as loan commitments and loans funded are up compared to last year. Although borrowers remain cautious, we're seeing areas of demand from customers in our corporate asset-based lending CRE and mortgage warehouse lending segment. With revenue demand, pricing and structure remains competitive. Our loan yields in the regional bank were relatively stable at 4.01% compared to last quarter's yield at 4.02%. Given the competitive environment, we expect yields will be under pressure. Nonetheless, new loans being booked in the regional bank continue to be better priced than regional banking and non-strategic assets that are running off our balance sheet.
Moving to expenses on Slide 10. We're very pleased with our continued progress here. Consolidated expenses declined 6% from last quarter. Regional banking expenses decreased 4% as we continue to implement cost-save initiatives. Productivity and efficiency actions in the third quarter include reductions of FTEs, lower discretionary spending and gaining efficiency from exited businesses. We will continue to evaluate efficiency actions such as consolidating branches and further process improvement, and we should also benefit from technology investments. Over the long term, we continue to target a 25% reduction from the level of 2010 consolidated expenses, mostly by the end of 2013.
Moving onto mortgage repurchase on Slide 11. Linked quarter, mortgage repurchase provision expense increased to $53 million from $25 million. Net realized losses matched provision, leaving reserves flat at $169 million. The rescission rate stayed steady in July and August but trended lower in September, reflecting a higher mix of mortgage insurance related resolutions, leading to higher loss content.
In the quarter, the GSEs made a push to resolve by September 30 unresolved repurchase claims based on MI coverage loss. To some extent, this accelerated charge-offs and contributed to third quarter's higher level of losses. Our operational pipeline dropped from $451 million to $418 million with new requests of $200 million and resolution of $237 million. The operational pipeline includes requests where mortgage insurance calculations are under review. Once this coverage is lost, it comes out of our operational pipeline, but we continue to consider these loans in the reserve calculation.
The GSEs appear to be more aggressive than the recovery efforts. Quarter-to-quarter, we are likely to see volatility in repurchase expense from the variances in the mix of both inflows and resolutions. Sitting here today, we expect our repurchase inflows to be reasonably steady, resolutions to continue to be strong, and we also still believe we're on the backside of GSE-related repurchase requests.
Moving to Slide 12, a minute on private mortgage securitizations. We still have had no repurchase requests from these securitizations to date. We still currently have 4 lawsuits related to private mortgage securitizations including the FHFA lawsuit. Our private mortgage securitizations have generally performed favorably overall of the industry cohort benchmarks. As you can see on this slide, 66% of private mortgage securitizations are outperforming industry cohort on cum loss, and 81% of these securitizations are outperforming cohorts on 60-day-plus delinquencies.
Our mix is different. We did no subprime, and additionally, reps and warranties are generally more limited than for GSE whole-loan sales. Considering the differences between the private securitizations and GSE loans that we've outlined on the slide, we continue to believe right now that our private securitization risk is likely to be significantly less than our experience with GSEs, which continues to be manageable as an earnings headwind.
Moving to asset quality on Slide 13. Credit quality metrics continue to be positive. NPAs declined. Net charge-offs, excluding the loan sales, were down. Loan sales of about $150 million and net book value included $126 million from our perm mortgage portfolio and about $24 million from our commercial loan portfolio. UPB on the sold loans was $220 million, reflecting a 47% blended mark on the loan sales. Reserves decreased $74 million, including $12 million associated with the loan sales. Despite several quarters, the reserve releases or reserves to loans remained healthy at $277 million. Given that our credit quality trends are generally favorable, we expect additional reserve releases, but the rate of reserve decrease could slow down depending on the economic environment.
Moving to Slide 14. Nonperforming assets declined 22% linked quarter, primarily due to the loan sales and upgrades in our commercial portfolios. In addition to broad-based improvement in our loan portfolios, we expect that the sale of nonperforming should be favorable to overall credit quality metrics in the future.
Wrapping up on Slide 15. Our core businesses showed good progress in reaching our long-term loans as target as we focus on controlling what we can control with solid trends in the regional bank, continued strong performance in our capital markets business and improving productivity and efficiency. Although the non-strategic segment and mortgage repurchase remain a drag, I'm pleased with the momentum in the bank and in our capital markets business. Bryan?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, BJ. Heading into the final quarter of 2011, I'm encouraged by the First Horizon team's progress in successfully executing our strategy, and I'm confident that we have the ability to continue to streamline and strengthen our business model, prof
componenttext:
Thank you, BJ. Heading into the final quarter of 2011, I'm encouraged by the First Horizon team's progress in successfully executing our strategy, and I'm confident that we have the ability to continue to streamline and strengthen our business model, profitably growing in our core businesses, significantly improving productivity and efficiency and favorably shifting our asset mix. We are also taking a disciplined approach to capital deployment, and today, we launched $100 million common stock repurchase program.
We and the industry are facing economic and regulatory headwinds and we remain in a slow growth environment, but with our dedicated team and customer focus, we will continue to make steady progress. Thank you, and now we'll take your questions. Operator?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011

componenttextpreview: This is Greg Jardine. Well, I think, couple things: One, that was a sale of nonperforming assets, and it was a bulk sale. And as I've mentioned in other calls, we explore the market all the time, and what we found in this particular case was that the bid
componenttext: This is Greg Jardine. Well, I think, couple things: One, that was a sale of nonperforming assets, and it was a bulk sale. And as I've mentioned in other calls, we explore the market all the time, and what we found in this particular case was that the bid ask was with in an area of which we felt comfortable with. So the 188 of UPB, the net book value was 67% of that, and so, we had a 60 -- another 68% execution against net book value, and we took a significant tail risk off by nonperforming perm mortgages. So in that case, Bob, we feel very comfortable. As you know, we have done some bulk sales not something of this size because we get basically good execution on one-off sales, but this made sense for the rate we got.

And when do you guys, if you used this as up, think you'd be eligible to go back and talk about increasing that?

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me try to start with the calendar. This is -- we think, based on everything we've been able to gather that the process around the other than 19 is not as structured a process, so we think it's a continuing dialogue with the regulators. So with th
componenttext: Yes, let me try to start with the calendar. This is -- we think, based on everything we've been able to gather that the process around the other than 19 is not as structured a process, so we think it's a continuing dialogue with the regulators. So with that said, we think that we have the opportunity to revisit the issue in the future. Now we made an initial request of $100 million from our perspective that capital management is a process. We'll work through it with the regulators, and we'll continue to evaluate the timing of repurchases and so on and so forth. So that was our initial request. We will work with the regulators in the future as we work through that. We'll continue to evaluate how we manage our capital base. As I've said in the past, we think that we have a very strong capital base. We think over time as the economy improve, we'll have a fair amount of excess capital to deploy, either in repurchasing stock or investment in the business. But we're going to be very disciplined in the way we do it, and that involves working with our regulators.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Zerbe of Morgan Stanley.

headline: First Horizon National Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2011
